{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3307149,"name":"Raunak Verma","username":"Raunak","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T19:07:33.787Z","cooked":"

Hi! Weâ€™re looking for advice on how to fix our Swerve Drive (MK4 L3 NEO), which keeps settling into a diamond position over time with the heading being diagonal. This is after cycling straight forward and backward with no input on the rotation axis. Additionally, our discretize function (set at 0.02) to keep the drivetrain from turning toward the direction it is rotating is no longer working.

image1920Ã—665 70.9 KB

(We know our speed is way off for the module states part on the left, Iâ€™d only look at the degree values)

Hereâ€™s a video of the discretize not working

At one point, we had code that mostly worked and did not have these issues, but it has since stopped working as intended. Our issues are relatively consistent and using advantagekit, we determined that our encoders are approximately 6 degrees off from their target state.

Our code is linked here.

Here are some things we tried to help fix the issue:

  • Rezeroed encoders in Phoenix Tuner
  • Replacing the battery
  • Recalibrating our pigeon
  • Tuned deadbands
  • Tuned the acceleration
  • Tuned discretize (which also isnâ€™t working)

We have not yet tried running any other repositories or base code, but if anyone has one that we should try or look into, we are open to trying it out!

Heading correction helped with this issue for YAGSL teams. You have to create a PID to correct your heading while there is no expected rotational component to your chassis speeds. You need to track the current heading while doing this too.

yesiconcur:

glass, which is an NI tool

Glass is a WPILib tool. AFAIK NI havenâ€™t been involved in developing Glass.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T07:26:25.295Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":73.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":454358,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally","display_username":"Davo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/dashboards/glass/introduction.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Introduction to Glass â€” FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":5},{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/tree/main/glass","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"allwpilib/glass at main Â· wpilibsuite/allwpilib Â· GitHub","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31229,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally/454358/7","custom_user_title":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3307471,"name":"Alexander Hamilton","username":"GalexY","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galexy/{size}/200203_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T07:44:47.862Z","cooked":"

I wanted to quickly mention that the most common reason this may be occurring is due to an offset gyroscope-- I would make sure your heading is correct before you do anything. With that being saidâ€¦ hereâ€™s a couple of things to note from my experience in understanding discretize:

  1. Discretize may not perfectly fix all drift issues, and requires a reliable dt that will not fluctuate. If you have no loop overruns, 0.02 is a great start. Read here on what an extra multiplier could do.
  2. It also relies on the idea that your swerveâ€™s PID is tuned correctly. If it takes a long time for a module to get to a desired speed, discretize will not help as much.
  3. When testing the effects of/tuning a multiplier for discretize, it is heavily recommended to turn off the driverâ€™s left/right motion. Make it so that they can only go forward, backward, and turn. This way, you know that there is no controller drift on the motion, whether that is through a controller or thumb which can help with getting more exact data on the issue.

I hope this helped narrow anything down and if you have more questions I think I am active enough to try to answer them. Everyone around here is pretty smart though, Iâ€™m not special

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T07:44:47.862Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":43,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":262.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":454358,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally","display_username":"Alexander Hamilton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/whitepaper-swerve-drive-skew-and-second-order-kinematics/416964/51","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54288,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4738 Programming Lead | Driver ðŸ¦’"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally/454358/8","custom_user_title":"4738 Programming Lead | Driver ðŸ¦’","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3308073,"name":"Raunak Verma","username":"Raunak","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-13T00:00:48.267Z","cooked":"

Weâ€™re struggling with implementing heading correction into our code. Below is the code weâ€™re working on in Swerve Subsystem:

public Command adjustHeading(){
    if(Math.abs(InputManager.getInstance().getControllerRotationalAxis()) <= 0.15) {
       for (SwerveModule module: modules) {
          double currentHeading = Math.toRadians(PIGEON.getYaw());
          double desiredHeading = module.getTargetState().angle.getRadians();
          PIDController headingController = new PIDController(1,0,0);
          headingController.enableContinuousInput(-Math.PI, Math.PI);
          drive(idk,idk,headingController.calculate(currentHeading,desiredHeading), POSE_ESTIMATOR.getEstimatedPose().getRotation());

       }
    }
}

Here is our drive method:

public void drive(double xVelocity, double yVelocity, double rotationalVelocity) {
		ChassisSpeeds speeds =
				ChassisSpeeds.fromFieldRelativeSpeeds(xVelocity, yVelocity, rotationalVelocity, POSE_ESTIMATOR.getEstimatedPose().getRotation());

		speeds = ChassisSpeeds.discretize(speeds, dtSeconds);
		SwerveModuleState[] states = kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(speeds);
		for (int i = 0; i < modules.length; i++) {
			modules[i].setState(states[i]);
		}
	}

Any advice or help on how to implement this would be appreciated!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-02-13T00:03:45.741Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":454358,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally","display_username":"Raunak Verma","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64188,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally/454358/9","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3308920,"name":"Raunak Verma","username":"Raunak","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-14T01:57:22.848Z","cooked":"

After taking a look, our gyroscope was indeed offset. Iâ€™m curious, how exactly can we compensate for this offset in code? Are there any guides or helpful pointers that we should look at?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-02-14T01:57:22.848Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":454358,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally","display_username":"Raunak Verma","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54288,"username":"GalexY","name":"Alexander Hamilton","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galexy/{size}/200203_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64188,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-keeps-drifting-diagonally/454358/10","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3309093,"name":"Alexander Hamilton","username":"GalexY","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galexy/{size}/200203_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-14T06:36:03.780Z","cooked":"

Most gyros allow you to reset their heading when the robot starts, the Pigeon 2.0 has a setYaw method and the ADIS16470 has a reset method. Those are the only two gyros Iâ€™ve used, but Iâ€™m sure each one has its way of zeroing it in code.
